instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.KERNEL_TASK: What is KERNEL_TASK? KERNEL_TASK is a process that will take up all the CPU and cause the macbook to run very slow when there is a sensor issue. When you see KERNEL_TASK as a process taking up lots of CPU and the machine is working very slow or has loud fans, use a program like hwmonitor to check voltage, amperage, and temperature sensors and look for something that doesn’t look right..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Hello guys,
I'm inspecting the schematics of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board and on page "Thermal Sensors"(page 44), there are a few acronyms such as: 
TBT,MLB, MLBBOT, TBD, CPU Proximity, Inlet ,DDR and BMON. What are these acronyms such as TBT TBD and MLB mean?
How these sensors works? All I can see on the schematics are BJT transistors. Are these BJTs actual thermal sensors? The lines are mutual for a couple of sensors so it is possible that one sensor causing problem and reporting multiple sensors failure.
Actually, the laptop has a problem, full speed fan and Facetime cannot work with message to wait until macbook cools down. So, temperature sensor near camera is failed. Is it possible to remove a resistor or make a jumper in order to bypass this. Fan is currently controled by Macs Fan control and laptop works OK. Zoom also works and camera is OK. There is no place on the computer that is heating, I checked this multiple times, so information about high temperature is fake.

I need a way to bypass this since I don't want to prevent me from normal using of the laptop. The laptop is not working slow.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Usually ALS sensor issue.
Test if fan spins normal, when diconnect webcam.
If yes, then cut off the traces from pins 8 & 9 if J4002.

As you can see in page 40, ALS sensor is connected in the same bus with <CHIP>U5800</CHIP>, which monitors above mentioned temps.
Of course, you can change LCD assembly...

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
TBT = Thunderbolt
MLB = Main Logic Board
BOT = Bottom
TBD = To Be Determined (ie. they didn't know where to place that sensor yet when designing schematics)
BMON = Battery monitoring

I might be wrong but I think it goes like this (unlike the hints in the schematics seem to imply, also note that it seems to be different from the 11" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>):
<TRANSISTOR>Q5810</TRANSISTOR> is TS2P Camera Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5820</TRANSISTOR> is THSP T29 Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5830</TRANSISTOR> is Ta0P Inlet
<TRANSISTOR>Q5840</TRANSISTOR> is TW0P Wireless Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5850</TRANSISTOR> is TM0P Memory Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5860</TRANSISTOR> is TCHP Charger Proximity
<CHIP>U5800</CHIP> is TC0P CPU Proximity
<CHIP>U5810</CHIP> is Tm0P Logic Board Top Side

ALS can indeed make all sensors connected to <CHIP>U5800</CHIP> to report errors.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos and piernov for the explanation. It is very strange to use use words proximity for thermal sensing since usually proximity sensors detects presence of an object in its vicinity.
Anyway, [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER], if you by "change LCD assembly" think this: [MEDIA=youtube]Zl2dtn8kPxA[/MEDIA] that is ofcourse out of the question. There is no way to remove screen because of one faulty sensor inside it.

When you say to cut off traces, you mean to use tweezers or something similar to cut (and break) traces i.e. to break conductive path?

Thank you once again.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Proximity means "near something", so here the sensors are near the CPU (rather than inside it, which is another sensor), near the RAM, near the Thunderbolt controller, near the camera controller, etc…

First you have to confirm if the sensors problem is solved after disconnecting webcam. Only then you can proceed onto thinking how to fix the problem…

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Yes, disconnecting cable that goes over I/O board caused fan to stop running at full speed.
I wonder how this really works. Does BJT starts conduction when temperature is high or something else? On the schematics, I can see that base and collector of BJT are shorted, and for the NPN transistor voltage between B and E should be above some trehold value in order transistor to start conducting (under assumption that collector is on positive potential).

In this case I have a clear sensor fail issue, since there is no spot on the board that is getting hot. From other posts I can see that these sensors fail upscale which means that temperature reading is above 100 degC

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
The bipolar transistor is used in B-E diode mode (short B/C), as temp sensor.
Any diode is sensitive to temperature changes, but simulated diode (with bipolar transistor) is even more sensitive.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: Thank you 2informaticos, very helpful.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Hello,
can someone please confirm that all <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MBA use the same trackpad flex cable? If I'm not mistaken this model is manufactured from 2013 to 2017.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: 2013-2017 is the same, 2012 is different.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Thank you piernov. Just one more question. Usually when sensor fails, CPU starts throttling and computer is very slow. I have found some information about the "<SIGNAL>KERNEL_TASK</SIGNAL>" activity in Activity monitor. I can use the laptop and watch YouTube/Netflix streaming without any glitches.
Maybe this is a stupid question, but I have no experience with MacBooks and especially macOS.
Activity monitor screenshot is attached. Is it possible to see if the laptop is entering "limp" mode occasionally from the Activity monitor?
Thank you!

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
piernov, are these sensors labels same on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, years 2013-2017)?

<TRANSISTOR>Q5810</TRANSISTOR> is TS2P Camera Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5820</TRANSISTOR> is THSP T29 Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5830</TRANSISTOR> is Ta0P Inlet
<TRANSISTOR>Q5840</TRANSISTOR> is TW0P Wireless Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5850</TRANSISTOR> is TM0P Memory Proximity
<TRANSISTOR>Q5860</TRANSISTOR> is TCHP Charger Proximity
<CHIP>U5800</CHIP> is TC0P CPU Proximity
<CHIP>U5810</CHIP> is Tm0P Logic Board Top Side

Thank you!

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>KERNEL_TASK</SIGNAL> taking 400% CPU time is forced software throttling. There's also hardware throttling that prevents the CPU from boosting or keeps it at the lowest core clock, can be seen with Intel Power Gadget: [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/Throttling[/URL]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is 2013-2014, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is 2015-2017. I think the sensors should be the same (still not 100% sure). I added the info there: [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/Mac_sensors_reference_designators[/URL]

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: Ok, thank you. I can conclude that there is no throttling on this MBA, which is "under observation". These sensors are really confusing me. without special control app, fan would go full speed. But the laptop works normal, wherever I found information about failed sensors it was also followed by slow computer response, throttling etc. On this particular laptop, youtubevideos can be watched without any glitches. The laptop unusually slow boots, but once the macOS is on, everything works OK. I'll examine further using Intel Power gadget.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
I have installed Intel Power Gadget and make a test. I have opened youtubevideo, thunderbird, Libre Office Writer, Spreadsheet and Presentation and during that time diagrams is recorded and given in the attachment. Because frequency is not getting above 1 GHz, does this mean that this MBA is actually hardware throttling or that CPU is kept from boosting?


I'd like to see this diagram on MBA 1466 without problem. During this test MBA was only on battery.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: Did you check the link I posted above? Of course you need to plot the graph while running a CPU stress test software.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
I did try to use Prime 95, but after downloading and extracting archive, I have tried to start Prime95 and got the following message:
"[B]“Prime95” can’t be opened because Apple cannot check it for malicious software."[/B]

Because of that I used CPU stress test and this is the diagram. Since CPU is i5 1.6GHz and there is a limit to 1 GHz, I can conclude that HW limitation of the CPU frequency is active on this MBA. Is this conclusion correct?

Thank you!

EDIT: In the sensor table list, ALS is mentioned at the begining but there is no sensor data in the table. Does ALS also belongs to SMC "3" SMBus?

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Right click → Open like for most apps downloaded outside the App Store.
That CPU is from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, not an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board like you said in the original post. In any case this i5-5250U boosts up to 2.5GHz all cores, so if you don't see it get to that frequency when stress-testing then there is a problem for sure.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
If you get errors about more temp sensors, there is not a problem with a particular sensor.
Various temp sensors are connected to the same bus through an interface.
If one interface fails, it will block correct comunication on that bus.
For this reason, SMC will cannot properly read several sensors connected to the same bus.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Yes, currently there are two laptops, both <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with the same/similar issue, one is 2014 and second one is 2015. 
On this from 2014, when disconnecting cable from J4002: Camera Connector, fan is not running full speed, so with help of 2informaticos it is concluded that it is most likely sensor in LCD assembly, and exchange it is not an option for the customer.
Then I tried 2015 laptop once again (here it is suspected that trackpad is causing the problem), but I saw in HW Monitor that all sensors <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_3</SIGNAL> reporting erroneous reading. 

I don't have a spare trackpad to test and can only bought one, but I'm not sure if this is a cause of the problem and don't want to wast money.

As 2informaticos wrote, this is not a problem with particular sensor, but with failed interface". By interface, you mean <CHIP>U5810</CHIP> chip, right?

I was thinking to disassemble and check for voltages from BJTs to try to see if problem is caused by one particular sensor, but it's not an option now.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Thermal sensor from trackpad has its interface.
If bad, it will affect the common bus.
<CHIP>U5810</CHIP> is probably good.
You can interchange 2014/15 trackpad, for test.
Try the flex first.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Open 2 threads for 2 different machines with different problems otherwise everyone will get confused.
If you suspect touchpad then just unplug it and see if the other sensors read correctly again.

If you are regularly repairing MacBooks you need to get some spare parts, in this case a spare <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013-2017 chassis would have allowed you to figure out that the problem is not from the logic board in 10 minutes of swapping it into the other chassis, rather than spending hours (and our time too) trying to figure out what's the problem with the logic board when it's not a logic board problem, even risking damaging it.

In any case you have 2 machines with the same chassis right now so you can easily confirm your suspicion by swapping display assembly and touchpad/touchpad cable.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: First of all, thank you all for your time. I have unplugged the touchpad flex cable 593-1604-B from the logic board, but same (in total 5) sensors still reported the same errors (128 deg C). I used external mouse and keyboard during this test and rhe same sensors are reported with high readings. Is it now reasonable to assume that the problem i most likely not caused by the trackpad? The swap of trackpads is not possible, there is a screw damage problem.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
Disconnecting trackpad flex, SMC will set fan to max; because cannot interrogate palm rest sensor.

You have similar machine.
Disconnect trackpad flex and see if get same errors there.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: Yes, I know that and already tried it. But I was expecting that my HW Monitor reports differently when trackpad is disconencted. Didn't expect airport proximity and mainboard proximity to stay 128C, I was expecting different reporting there no matter the fan full blast.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: So, good machine reports the same errors?

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: Yes that is why it is so confusing. Two memory (bank and proximity), palmrest mainboard and airport. All 5 sensors to 128C even when trackpad is unplugged. I think this 'meomory proximity" is non existant.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message: If you get same behaviour without trackpad flex on the known good working board, why do you suspect something else than trackpad???

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
I have two machines, both has sensors issues and reporting multiple senors failure in HWMonitor On first one fan is not full blast if I disconnect camera cable but reports many sensor failures.

I'll try to obtain a fully functional <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with no sensor issues to test what is reported when trackpad flex cable is unplugged.

threads.title: Macbook Air 1466 Thermal Sensors
threads.message:
So one machine works good, but gets strange temps disconnecting webcam?
If this machine has good trackpad, install the other board in this shell.
